thread.title: Nissan to double number of UK-sourced parts as Sunderland plant grows, reports say

author: Jonathon Manning
title: Nissan to double number of UK-sourced parts as Sunderland plant grows, reports say
text:

Automotive giant Nissan has distanced itself from reports that suggested a potential Brexit jobs boost for the North East. 
The respected Nikkei Asian Review had claimed that the Japanese car giant intends to increase production at its Sunderland plant by 20%, while also doubling the amount of parts it sources from UK companies. 
According to the report, the plans were designed to offset higher costs associated with Britain leaving the EU, with a potential boost for the International Advanced Manufacturing Park being on the boundary of Sunderland and South Tyneside if Nissan used more UK suppliers. 
The Nikkei report claimed that Nissan was planning to increase the 40% of the parts used in its Sunderland plant to 80% to avoid tariffs and delays in the manufacturing process. Read More Government accused of 'bowing to Nissan's demands' to keep carmaker in the North East after Brexit 
Nissan has not commented on the reports, but it is understood that the company does not recognise the claims. 
Nissan has attempted to stay out of the Brexit debate as far as is possible, knowing that both sides of the EU debate use the company as a bellwether for how the UK will react to leaving the EU. 
Last year the firm said it would be building the new Qashqai and X-Trail models at Sunderland, resulting in a big increase in production numbers at the plant. The announcement came after Nissan received Government assurances that EU withdrawal would not affect the plant’s competitiveness. Electric vehicles at Nissan's manufacturing plant at Sunderland (Image: nissan) 
But company executives have since said that it would “re-evaluate the situation” once the final Brexit deal is concluded, making it clear to the Government that future trading arrangements at Europe could affect jobs in the North East. 
Nissan employs nearly 7,000 people at its Sunderland plant with a further 20,000 in the supply chain, while the automotive park being built close to the plant is seen as a major hope for new employment in the North East. Read More Nissan sells Sunderland battery manufacturing business as part of global deal 
The reports have come with Prime Minister Theresa May set to visit Japan tomorrow for trade talks with Japanese PM Shinzo Abe. 
Nissan is one of a number of big Japanese employers in the North East and politicians in that country have warned that Brexit could jeapordize investment in the UK. Like us on Facebook
